abstracts.cdata!:
Most of the negative environmental
            impacts associated with sub-projects in the National
            Community Development Project for Jamaica are likely to
            occur during construction and rehabilitative works on roads,
            buildings, drainage, and water and sanitation projects and
            where designs are inadequate. These tend to be minor and are
            easily identified and mitigated and determination of the
            potential impact forms and integral part of the analysis of
            the technical feasibility of the projects. Dust and noise
            should be minimized; when sand is used to fill in land or to
            level a site, it must be capped with clay turf, whenever
            possible, otherwise, spray the area with water to minimize
            dust; limit work to daylight hours and warn residents when
            blasting occurs; use silt screens and straw devices to
            prevent siltation of watercourses; minimize tree clearing
            and other vegetation; dispose of waste in approved
            dumpsites. Negative impacts will also occur during operation
            particularly regarding disposal of solid and sewage waste,
            where there are improper operational and maintenance
            procedures in place.
